content: quote: Originally posted by SSgtRobertMorris: quote: Originally posted by jwr6: But, since you mentioned it, I can see the "standard" 50% retirement w/ free healthcare for 20 years active service changing at some point in the future. It already is gone. As far as I know, the last 20 yr 50%ers enlisted sone time during the late '80's, early '90's. I think you have to do 30 to get 50% now. That is incorrect. Military retirement is on three systems now depending on DIEMS date. Prior to a September 1980 entry it is based on your final pay, 50% at 20 years and 2.5% for each year after up to 75%. Under Carter the retirment systme was changed. September 1980 to August 1986 is the same, except pay is computed on the average of your final three years pay. This is the High 3 system. Under Reagan the retirement system was changed to under 50% at 20 years. In 1986 the retirement system was changed to 40% at 20 years, but a 3.5% increase per year so at 30 years it would be 75%. There is also a readjustment that beings it back to the same as High 3 at age 62. This is called Redux. That was changed again in 1999 under Clinton, with the FY 2000 Defense Budget. Now people that entered after 1986 have the option of choosing between the High 3 system, or taking a $30,000 payment at 15 years of service and the Redux retirement. I entered in August 95, so in Feb 2010 at my 14.5 year point I have to decide between Redux and the $30,000 payment and High 3. I'll be taking the High 3 since it will be at least $150,000 difference in retirement pay from the time I retire at about age 42 until Redux would catch up at 62. Since the law was changed before anyone under redux actually had 20 years, there is nobody that was forced to retire with less than the full 50% at 20 years.

content: quote: Originally posted by SSgtRobertMorris: quote: Originally posted by jwr6: But, since you mentioned it, I can see the "standard" 50% retirement w/ free healthcare for 20 years active service changing at some point in the future. It already is gone. As far as I know, the last 20 yr 50%ers enlisted sone time during the late '80's, early '90's. I think you have to do 30 to get 50% now. That is incorrect. Military retirement is on three systems now depending on DIEMS date. Prior to a September 1980 entry it is based on your final pay, 50% at 20 years and 2.5% for each year after up to 75%. Under Carter the retirment systme was changed. September 1980 to August 1986 is the same, except pay is computed on the average of your final three years pay. This is the High 3 system. Under Reagan the retirement system was changed to under 50% at 20 years. In 1986 the retirement system was changed to 40% at 20 years, but a 3.5% increase per year so at 30 years it would be 75%. There is also a readjustment that beings it back to the same as High 3 at age 62. This is called Redux. That was changed again in 1999 under Clinton, with the FY 2000 Defense Budget. Now people that entered after 1986 have the option of choosing between the High 3 system, or taking a $30,000 payment at 15 years of service and the Redux retirement. I entered in August 95, so in Feb 2010 at my 14.5 year point I have to decide between Redux and the $30,000 payment and High 3. I'll be taking the High 3 since it will be at least $150,000 difference in retirement pay from the time I retire at about age 42 until Redux would catch up at 62. Since the law was changed before anyone under redux actually had 20 years, there is nobody that was forced to retire with less than the full 50% at 20 years.
